theme.title: The eighth note
theme.para: The next figure we are going to study is the eighth note (also called 'quaver' in British English). Its symbols are shown in the followig score, and are like a quarter note with a flag added to its stem; they are usually drawn beamed:

score.music: (n c5 c)(n f4 c)(espacio 20)(Barra Doble) (n c4 c g+)(n g4 c g-)(n b4 c g+)(n e5 c g-)(Barra Doble) (n c5 c g+)(n e5 c)(n b4 c)(n d4 c g-)(Barra Doble) (n e4 c g+)(n g4 c)(n f4 c)(n a4 c g-)(Barra Final))

theme.para: One quarter note equals two eighth notes and one quarter rest equals two eighth rests. So in 2/4 time signature an eighth note or rest gets half a beats, and, therefore, there are two eighth notes in a beat. So in 2/4 they are usually drawn beamed, occupying a beat.
In this lesson we will start the study of rhythms with eighth notes. Play the following score and take note of the newly rhythmic patterns introduced in each measure:

score.music: (score (vers 1.5)(language en iso-8859-1) (instrument (musicData (clef G)(key C) (time 2 4) (n g4 q)(n g4 e g+)(n g4 e g-)(barline) (n g4 e g+)(n g4 e g-)(n g4 q)(barline) (n g4 e g+)(n g4 e)(n g4 e)(n g4 e g-)(barline) (n g4 q)(r q) (barline end) )))
